qas.question: When did the Fed begin raising Fed funds rate significantly?
How do asset prices generally move in relation to interest rates?
Beginning in July 2004, what did the Fed do to make ARM rates more expensive for homeowners?
How did U.S. housing and financial assets react to the housing bubble burst?

context: The Fed then <a3_0>raised the Fed funds rate<a3_0/> significantly between <a0_0>July 2004<a0_0/> and July 2006. This contributed to an increase in 1-year and 5-year <a1_0>adjustable-rate mortgage<a1_0/> (ARM) rates, making ARM interest rate resets more expensive for homeowners. This may have also contributed to the deflating of the housing bubble, as asset prices generally move <a2_0>inversely<a2_0/> to interest rates, and it became riskier to speculate in housing. U.S. housing and financial assets <a4_0>dramatically declined in value<a4_0/> after the housing bubble burst.
